Let's cook EASY + AUTHENTIC Japanese recipes at home!
Konnichiwa! I'm Nami, the creator of the Just One Cookbook website and cooking blog. I am glad that you are here with me. Here and on JustOneCookbook.com, you can find over 1,200 recipes, cooking tips, step-by-step instructions, ingredients, and shopping guides focused on Japanese cuisine.

I'm a native Japanese, born and raised in Yokohama, Japan, and now live in San Francisco, California, with my husband Mr. JOC, two high school kids, and a dog named Miso. I also wrote three Japanese cookbooks, where I share popular recipes like Oyakodon, Tamagoyaki, Chawanmushi, Sushi, Okonomiyaki, Mochi Ice Cream, Gyoza, Ramen, and more!

itemListElement.text: Gather all the ingredients to make the onigiri and a bowl filled with water for your hands. If you are shaping the onigiri with your hands, transfer the freshly cooked rice to a large bowl, baking sheet, or sushi oke (hangiri) and let it cool slightly until it‚Äòs cool enough to handle. The rice should be warm when making onigiri.

The rice should be warm when making onigiri.

itemListElement.text: Prepare another bowl filled with water. Soak the onigiri mold and lid in the water to moisten so the rice doesn‚Äòt stick to it. Remove the mold and drain the excess water. Next, sprinkle salt in the moistened mold. Salt is used not only for seasoning but also for food safety.

Next, sprinkle salt in the moistened mold. Salt is used not only for seasoning but also for food safety.

itemListElement.text: Fill it halfway with warm rice, making sure the rice is filled to the corners. Add a spoonful of your filling of choice.
itemListElement.name: Fill it halfway with warm rice, making sure the rice is filled to the corners. Add a spoonful of your filling of choice.

itemListElement.text: Fill the rest of the mold with more rice, all the way to the edges. Sprinkle the top of the rice with more salt.
itemListElement.name: Fill the rest of the mold with more rice, all the way to the edges. Sprinkle the top of the rice with more salt.

itemListElement.text: Cover with the lid and push down firmly. You should feel a slight resistance to it; if not, you may want to add a bit more rice. Remove the lid, flip the mold over, and push the ‚Äúbutton‚Äù to release your¬†onigiri onto a baking sheet or plate lined with parchment paper. Repeat with the remaining rice. Tip: Always dip your fingers in water before touching the onigiri to prevent the rice from sticking to your fingers.

itemListElement.text: First, wet both of your palms with a bit of water to prevent the rice from sticking to your hands. Then, apply some Diamond Crystal kosher salt and spread it on both palms. How much salt? I dip 2‚Äì3 fingers in the kosher salt, as pictured below. If you are using table salt, use half the amount as it‚Äôs saltier than kosher salt.

itemListElement.text: Scoop a handful (about ‚Öì cup, 50 g) of slightly cooled but still hot rice onto your left (non-dominant) hand. Tip: Your left hand holds the rice ball and flattens the onigiri‚Äôs sides. Always keep it underneath the onigiri. Create a small well (indentation) in the center of the rice. Add 1‚Äì2 tsp of one kind of filling inside.

itemListElement.text: Scoop some more rice (another ‚Öì cup, 50 g) to cover your filling completely. Mold the rice with your hands and gently press the rice around the filling to form the rice into a ball.

itemListElement.text: Bend your right (dominant) hand slightly to form a ‚Äúmountain‚Äù shape and place it on top of the rice. Your right hand forms the triangle corners of the onigiri. Always keep it on top of the rice ball.Gently press the rice with your top hand to make a triangle corner. Tip: Make your hands just firm enough so the onigiri doesn‚Äôt fall apart, but don‚Äôt squeeze too tightly. Try to keep the density of the rice ball as airy as possible.At the same time, squeeze the fingers and heel of your bottom (left) hand on either side of the onigiri to gently press the sides flat.Now, rotate the triangle corner you just made toward you. I use a single upward motion to barely toss the rice ball in my bottom hand while I use my top hand to rotate it toward me clockwise (since I‚Äôm right-handed). The first corner will now point at you while the tip of the second corner points up.Repeat the ‚Äúpress and rotate‚Äù steps to form the second and third triangle corners. Then press and rotate 2‚Äì3 more times to finish shaping the triangle.

recipeInstructions.name: To Wrap with the Nori and Serve

itemListElement.text: Toast 3 sheets nori (dried laver seaweed) over an open flame one by one.
itemListElement.name: Toast 3 sheets nori (dried laver seaweed) over an open flame one by one.

itemListElement.text: Then, cut them into thirds, parallel to the lines on the nori sheet.
itemListElement.name: Then, cut them into thirds, parallel to the lines on the nori sheet.

itemListElement.text: Style A: Wrap a strip of nori on one side of the onigiri. For this style, you may need to cut the nori into shorter and narrower strips.
itemListElement.name: Style A: Wrap a strip of nori on one side of the onigiri. For this style, you may need to cut the nori into shorter and narrower strips.

itemListElement.text: Enjoy the onigiri warm or at room temperature.
itemListElement.name: Enjoy the onigiri warm or at room temperature.

itemListElement.text: Style B: Wrap the onigiri with a piece of nori seaweed. If you like crispy nori, then wait to wrap the nori until right before consuming the onigiri. Make sure to keep the nori in an airtight container or bag so it will not get stale.

itemListElement.text: Place a little bit of each filling on the tip of the onigiri so you can identify which filling is inside. Enjoy the onigiri warm or at room temperature.

itemListElement.text: If you‚Äòd like to pack Onigiri for your lunch, keep it cool and consume it within 6 hours. Onigiri (or any rice dish) gets hard when you refrigerate it. The cold air makes the rice dry and hard. I don‚Äòt recommend making onigiri too far ahead of time. But if you really need to, my trick is to wrap the onigiri with thick kitchen towels and store it in the fridge. The onigiri will be cool and safe but should not get cold.
